quoteFirst: Fowler had hired a cab by the hour, with a promise of double fare to the driver, to whom he gave explicit instructions. We did not enter the house; we lingered at the corner of a street at some distance from it, and at
quoteLast: Miss Ida White closed the street door behind her. Secret signals passed between Fowler and his men, and we followed the lady's-maid, the cab which Fowler had engaged crawling in our rear without attracting attention.
title: The Nine of Hearts: A Novel
author: Farjeon, B. L. (Benjamin Leopold), 1833-1903

quoteLast: Laid to off Ambrose Light Vessel at 1.20 P.M.

quoteFirst: Having left Paris at
quoteLast: , we reached Marseilles at nearly midnight, feeling very tired, and were glad to get to the Terminus Hotel, which is comfortably close to the station. What a charming station it is, with its courtyard and garden, orange trees and flowering myrtles!
title:
Fair Italy, the Riviera and Monte Carlo
Comprising a Tour Through North and South Italy and Sicily with a Short Account of Malta
author: Devereux, W. Cope

quoteFirst: Would it be quiet in the pool by the mill? Eleanor slipped unsteadily into the bottom of her boat and tried to peer through the darkness at the black water, and to feel about with her hands for the current. As she did so, a bell rang up on the campus. It must be
quoteLast: . Eleanor gave a harsh, mirthless laugh. How stupid she had been! She would call, of course.
title: Betty Wales, Freshman
author: Dunton, Edith K. (Edith Kellogg), 1875-1944

quoteFirst: Central Railway, they reached Tula at
quoteLast: ; the distance is about fifty miles, and the route is the same as already described, through the Nochistongo cut. The returning train at 4.40 P.M. brought them back to the city at seven o'clock, and the trio unanimously voted that they had passed a most agreeable and instructive day.
title:
The Boy Travellers in Mexico
Adventures of Two Youths in a Journey to Northern and Central Mexico, Campeachey, and Yucatan, With a Description of the Republics of Central America and of the Nicaragua Canal

quoteFirst: The Queen and Prince were more than ever impressed that the strength of Cherbourg was a menace to England, and called the attention of their own Ministers, who were in attendance, to the obvious necessity for England to look more sharply to her coast and naval defences. How thankful Her Majesty must have been when the end of each day’s festivity was reached! Even in the diary the mere words form a little oasis, “At
quoteLast: we went below, and read and nearly finished that most interesting book, ‘Jane Eyre.’”
title: Life of Her Majesty Queen Victoria
author: Fawcett, Millicent Garrett, Dame, 1847-1929

quoteFirst: "Leave Treseburg at
quoteLast: over a bridge on the right bank of the Bode. Altenbrack at 10.50, Wendefurth at 11.50. Rubeland reached at 2.30 P.M., and so on to Elbingerode, where a halt is made for the night at the 'Blauer Engel,' a tolerable inn. Women of burden and foresters are the only wayfarers met with.

quoteFirst: They had for a target nothing but the thin smoke which rose over his gun, but into that little floating cloud they planted shot and shell, until at the end of the day they had given out 210 rounds, if I remember the extraordinary figure correctly. All the other Boer guns were silenced before this one was, and at
quoteLast: this was silenced and every gun of the enemy was speechless."
title: With the Flag to Pretoria: A History of the Boer War of 1899-1900. Volume 1
author: Wilson, Herbert Wrigley, 1866-1940

quoteFirst: Unless their speed had been reduced by our fire, while we ought to have gained, we should hardly have caught up so much as in the first hour and a half. But there had, besides, been two destroyer attacks threatened or made by the enemy, one apparently at about
quoteLast: , and one at some time between then and 10:40. It is highly probable that each of these attacks caused the British squadron to change course, and we know that before 10:45 the stations had been altered.
title: The British Navy in Battle
author: Pollen, Arthur Joseph Hungerford, 1866-1937

quoteFirst: Both cruisers were now visible from the upper bridge of the _Invincible_; and the tops of the _Invincible_ and _Inflexible_ must have been equally apparent to them; though it still seems uncertain whether they had positively identified yet the two great cruisers that spelt their doom.  Meanwhile, in the harbour, every preparation was being pushed forward with the utmost speed.  At
quoteLast: the _Glasgow_ weighed anchor and steamed down the harbour to join the _Kent_.  Next to the two battle-cruisers, she {67} was the speediest vessel in the squadron, and her orders were to observe the enemy.
title: The Heroic Record of the British Navy: A Short History of the Naval War, 1914-1918
author: Hurd, Archibald, 1869-1959; Bashford, H. H. (Henry Howarth), Sir, 1880-1961

quoteFirst: It was, then, about
quoteLast: on the night of the fourth of June, eighteen hundred and eighty-six, that, after disposing of a pint of beer and a Welsh rarebit for my supper, I seated myself in my arm-chair, cocked my feet upon a stool, and lit my pipe, as was my custom.
title: The Great Keinplatz Experiment and Other Tales of Twilight and the Unseen
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan, 1859-1930
